div.head:
EmblemeEmblem 6. Of the Secrets of Nature.
Sowesow your gold in the white foliated earth.

lg.l: Rusticks their seed to th' fertile earth committ,
When with their harrows they have made it fitt:
The Sophi thus their golden seed due sowe
In foliated earth as white as Snow:
This method well observed, and you'le behold,
As in a glasse, by wheat, your budding gold.

div.head: Discourse 6.
div.ab:
A City sayth plato subsiste not by physician and physician, but by physician and
husbandman, that is, men of divers functions, but here mentions the husbandman
and physician first, because their worke are very conspicuous in the imitation,
emendation, and perfection of nature: for they both take a naturall subject,
in which they attending to art add some certaine things necessary being wanting,
or allso remove those things which are superfluous: soe that the art of both may
(as medicine by Hippocrates) be defined by the addition of defect, and subtract
tion of superfluity: for what do the husbandman more than add ploughing, ridging
furrowing, harrowing, dunging or manuring, sowing, et. to land left by nature, that
is, commit the increase and good successe to nature, which administreth the heat
of the Sunne, and raine, and multiplyes the seeds by them, and promotes them to
standing corne soon after to be reeped: in the
Discourse 3.
- - - - -
